Package com.kuka.roboticsAPI.applicationModel.tasks

The task and it's injected dependencies will be able to use the following types using dependency injection (using @Inject and @Named): General purpose types: LBR* RoboticArm* Tool* PhysicalObject* VirtualObject* IProcessData** ISceneGraph Control types: IApplicationUI ITaskLogger ObserverManager IProcessDataManager User defined types: All custom tool types that inherit from Tool.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    IRoboticsAPITaskInjectableTypes
    The following types and services are available for injection with @Inject.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    RoboticsAPIBackgroundTask
    Base class for RoboticsAPI background task.
    RoboticsAPICyclicBackgroundTask
    Base class for cyclic background tasks.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    CycleBehavior
    Defines the behavior of a cyclic task if the execution of a cyclic method takes longer than the specified period of time.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    CycleExceededException
    Thrown when execution of cyclic task method takes longer than the specified period time of a cyclic task.
    CyclicTaskException
    Exception that is thrown if cyclic background task is ended because of unhandled exception in RoboticsAPICyclicBackgroundTask.runCyclic() method.

Package com.kuka.roboticsAPI.applicationModel.tasks Description

The task and it's injected dependencies will be able to use the following types using dependency injection (using @Inject and @Named):

  • General purpose types:
    • LBR*
    • RoboticArm*
    • Tool*
    • PhysicalObject*
    • VirtualObject*
    • IProcessData**
    • ISceneGraph
  • Control types:
    • IApplicationUI
    • ITaskLogger
    • ObserverManager
    • IProcessDataManager
  • User defined types:
    • All custom tool types that inherit from Tool. ***
    • All custom physical objects types that inherit from PhysicalObject ***
    • All custom virtual objects types that inherit from VirtualObject ***
  • Generated IO-Groups:
    • All generated IO-Group types. Every IO-Group type will be injected as Singleton.
  • Special purpose types (use only if you know what you're doing):
    • IRecovery
Notes:
* : If there's more than one device, controller or template configured in the station, you must specify the name with @Named. The device and controller names have to be unique in the station.

** : The respective ID must be given with @Named

*** : Type is "Non-Singleton" unless it is annotated with @Singleton. This will create a new instance of the type on each injection. Custom types need to have either an annotated or an empty argument constructor.

Injection can only be used in the declaration area of a class or method, not inside of body of methods. The example below will show how to use injection in tasks:

File RoboticsAPI.ProcessData.xml 

<processDataContainer version="4"\>
    <processData dataType="java.lang.Boolean" defaultValue="true" displayName="Do process" id="doProcess" value="true"/>
    <processData dataType="java.lang.Boolean" defaultValue="false" displayName="Is empty" id="isEmpty" value="false"/>
    <processData dataType="java.lang.Integer" defaultValue="0" displayName="Example Integer" id="counter" max="100" min="0" value="82" comment="This is a comment."/>
    <processData dataType="java.lang.String" defaultValue="0" displayName="Example String" id="OtherChannelParam" value="Param for OtherChannel">
        <channel id="SmartHMI" isWriteable="true"/>
        <channel id="OtherChannel" isWriteable="true"/>
    </processData>
</processDataContainer>

Example application (also valid for background tasks) 

public class InjectionExample extends RoboticsAPIApplication {
    @Inject
    private ITaskLogger logger;
    @Inject
    private Tool gripper;
    @Inject
    @Named ("doProcess")
    private IProcessData startProcess;

    @Override
    public void initialize() {
        // ...
    }

    @Override
    public void run() {
        // ...
        if (startProcess.getValue()) {
            logger.info("Process starts now.");
            gripper.move(lin(...));
            // ...
        }        
        // ...
    }
}
